column1: For a set this size three minidolls and five animals was good.
column2: It is a pet centre so one would expect quite a few animals.&nbsp
column3: Two were downstairs and the other three were upstairs so well distributed through the centre.

column1: I am always amused that Lego put in an American style fire hydrant whereas in the UK these are underground.
The usual colours that one associates with Friends were evident.
column2: I liked the lime and bright light orange canopy at the front of the building.&nbsp
column3: The paw print was a nice touch made up of a dark pink 4x4 circle plate and white round tiles for the paw pad and toes.

column1: The ambulance was quite small with room for one driver and you could just get Lady the poodle in the back.
column2: Definitely no room for anything bigger than that!&nbsp
column3: Not quite sure what the thinking was behind having the red warning light on top of the ambulance being able to fold down.

column1: I was intrigued by the archway in the middle for small animals to go through.
column3: hope that there was some means to block that off at night when the centre was closed.&nbsp
column4: Goodness knows what havoc Mia might have found when she returned the next day.&nbsp

column1: There is the usual level of detail that you get with Friends sets. A good window display with Harry and Bubbles
column2: looking out at the people passing by.&nbsp
column3: At the back food to buy, a fish tank and a delightful conveyor belt.&nbsp
column4: I rather enjoyed that, twiddling the red knob to make it move.

column1: Upstairs was for pet pampering and any medical attention that your pet might need.
column2: Lady was waiting for her grooming whilst Mini and Mimi were on the seesaw and swing.
